questions.text: On which chromosome does the extra copy of genetic material present in a child having Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Down syndrome, characterized by extra copy of genes on chromosome 21, is the most common of the chromosomal disorders. About 95% of affected persons have trisomy 21, so their chromosome count is 47.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-264)

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the marker for Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumour?
questions.solution:
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, and more than half of these tumors occur in the stomach. A wide variety of other mesenchymal neoplasms may arise in the stomach. The most common genetic change underlying the pathogenesis of GISTs is gain-of-function mutations of the gene encoding the tyrosine kinase KIT, the receptor for stem cell factor.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-606-07)

questions.text: Which amongst the following is the characteristic finding of Papillary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin, which imparts an optically clear or empty appearance, giving rise to the designation ground-glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei. In addition, invaginations of the cytoplasm often give the appearance of intranuclear inclusions (“pseudo-inclusions”) or intranuclear grooves. These nuclear features are sufficient for the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, even in the absence of papillary architecture.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-766).

questions.text: Which leukemia show monosomy 5 and 7 cytogenetic abnormality?
questions.solution:
The term myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) refers to a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects that are associated with ineffective hematopoiesis and a high risk of transformation to AML. Both primary MDS and therapy-related MDS are associated with similar recurrent chromosomal abnormalities, including monosomies 5 and 7, deletions of 5q, 7q, and 20q, and trisomy 8.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-481)

questions.text: Commonest variety of acute inflammation is-
questions.solution:
Catarrhal inflammation: An inflammatory process that occur in mucous membrane and is characterized by increased blood flow to the mucosal vessel, edema of interstitial tissue, enlargement of the secretory gland epithelial cells and profuse discharge of mucus and epithelial debris.

(Chandrasoma Taylor,3th ed, Pg-45)

questions.text: Which component degrades Fibrin?
questions.solution:
Coagulation must be balanced with fibrinolysis to limit haemolytic plug to the site of injury.

Injured vascular epithelium secret plasminogen activator that converts inactive plasminogen into active plasmin. Plasmin breaks down fibrin resulting in production of fibrin degradation products.

Fibrinolytic system is regulated by plasminogen activator inhibitors that are secreted by endothelium.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-116)

questions.text: All of the followings are associated with sicca syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Sjögren syndrome is a chronic disease characterized by dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia) resulting from immunologically mediated destruction of the lacrimal and salivary glands. It occurs as an isolated disorder (primary form), also known as the sicca syndrome, or more often in association with another autoimmune disease (secondary form). Rheumatoid arthritis is the most common associated disorder, while other patients have SLE, polymyositis, scleroderma, vasculitis, mixed connective tissue disease, or autoimmune thyroid disease.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-158)

questions.text: Which amongst the following is a simple bacterial test for mutagenic carcinogen?
questions.solution:
Ames test is a simple test developed by Bruce Ames that measures the potential of a given chemical compound to promote mutations in a specialized bacterial strain.

(Lehninger, 4th ed, Pg-967)

questions.text: Which is the characteristic feature of malignant hypertension?
questions.solution:
Malignant hypertension, defined as blood pressure usually greater than 200/120 mm Hg.

Damage to the small vessels is manifested as fibrinoid necrosis of the arterioles (Fig. 14.19A). The vessel walls show a homogeneous, granular eosinophilic appearance masking underlying detail. In the interlobular arteries and larger arterioles, proliferation of intimal cells after acute injury produces an onion-skin appearance. This name is derived from the concentric arrangement of cells whose origin is believed to be intimal smooth muscle, although this issue has not been finally settled. This lesion, called hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, causes marked narrowing of arterioles and small arteries, to the point of total obliteration.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-570)

questions.text: What amongst following is in largest number in a normal bone marrow?
questions.solution:
In bone marrow Myeloid : Erythroid ratio is 3:1 or 4:1.

Amongst the myeloid series, metamyelocytes are maximum.

(Harshmohan, 4th ed, Pg-335)

questions.text: In thromboasthenia, there is defect in-
questions.solution:
The conformational change in glycoprotein IIb/IIIa that occurs with platelet activation allows binding of fibrinogen, a large bivalent plasma polypeptide that forms bridges between adjacent platelets, leading to their aggregation. Predictably, inherited deficiency of GpIIb-IIIa results in a bleeding disorder called Glanzmann thrombasthenia

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-103)

questions.text: Which parameter is assessed by Hess test?
questions.solution:
Hess capillary resistant test or tourniquet test is done by sphygmomanometer cuff.

Presence of more than 20 petechaie over the cubital fossa is considered positive test.

The test is positive in increased capillary fragility as well as in thrombocytopenia.

(Harshmohan, 4th ed, Pg-393)

questions.text: Hairy cell leukemia is a neoplastic proliferation of?
questions.solution:
Hairy cell leukemia is an uncommon, indolent B cell neoplasm characterized by the presence of fine, hairlike cytoplasmic projections. The tumor cells express B cell markers (CD20), surface immunoglobulin, and CD11c and CD103; the latter two antigens are not present on most other B cell tumors, making them diagnostically useful. Virtually all cases are associated with activating mutations in the serine/threonine kinase BRAF, which is also mutated in diverse other cancers.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 7th ed, Pg-477)

questions.text: X bodies called Birbeck granules are charcterisitcally seen in-
questions.solution:
The term histiocytosis is an “umbrella” designation for a variety of proliferative disorders of dendritic cells or macrophages. Langerhans cell proliferations take on different clinical forms, but all are believed to be variations of the same basic disorder. The proliferating Langerhans cells express MHC class II antigens, CD1a, and langerin. Langerin is a transmembrane protein found in Birbeck granules, cytoplasmic pentalaminar rodlike tubular structures that in electron micrographs have a characteristic periodicity and sometimes a dilated terminal end (“tennis racket” appearance).

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-484)

questions.text: Familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy is due to amyloidosis of nerves caused by the deposition of
questions.solution: (Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-184)

questions.text: In which amongst following Basophilic leucocytosis is seen?
questions.solution:
Basophilic Leukocytosis (Basophilia) Rare, often indicative of a myeloproliferative neoplasm (e.g.chronic myeloid leukemia)

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-460)

questions.text: Heart failure cells contain?
questions.solution:
Heart failure cells are hemosiderin laden alveolar macrophages. They are manifestation of pulmonary congestion and edema.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-680)

questions.text: Which is the most common source of pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
Pulmonanry embolism is blockage of pulmonary artery or one of its branches.

The most common site of DVT- calf veins

The most common source of pulmonary embolism- DVT of proximal veins of lower limb i.e. popliteal, femoral or iliac veins.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-706)

questions.text: Cast is produced due to damage to?
questions.solution:
Urinary cast are cylindrical aggregation of particulate matter that form in distal convulated tubulr or the collecting duct. They form via precipitation of Tam-Horsfall mucoprotein.

(Harrison, 17th ed, Pg-272-273,1758)

questions.text: Which is the most common pathological feature of kidney in diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
The kidneys are prime targets of diabetes. Renal failure is second only to myocardial infarction as a cause of death from this disease. The lesions include mainly: (1) glomerular lesions; (2) renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis; and (3) pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis. The most important glomerular lesions are capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis. The glomerular capillary basement membranes are thickened along their entire length.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-780)

questions.text: Which is the most common site of peptic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) most often is associated with H. pylori infection or NSAID use. The imbalances of mucosal defenses and damaging forces that cause chronic gastritis.

It is predominately located along the lesser curvature.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-776)

questions.text: Which amongst the following best differentiate between ulcerative colitis and crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Panth cells are specific type of cells within crypt of liberkuhn.

These cells have atypically oriented bright eosinophilic granules containing a variety of antimicrobial proteins and play a role in mucosal immunity (and not mucin secretion).

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 7th ed, Pg-829)

questions.text: Which polyp has least malignant potential?
questions.solution:
Colonic hyperplastic polyps are common epithelial proliferations that typically are discovered in the sixth and seventh decades of life. Although these lesions have no malignant potential, they must be distinguished from sessile serrated adenomas, histologically similar lesions that have malignant potential.

Hyperplastic polyps are most commonly found in the left colon and typically are less than 5 mm in diameter.They are smooth, nodular protrusions of the mucosa, often on the crests of mucosal folds. They may occur singly but more frequently are multiple, particularly in the sigmoid colon and rectum. Histologically, hyperplastic polyps are composed of mature goblet and absorptive cells. The delayed shedding of these cells leads to crowding that creates the serrated surface architecture, the morphologic hallmark of these lesions.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-627)

questions.text: Which of the following show councilman bodies?
questions.solution:
Acute viral hepatitis. Grossly, livers involved by mild acute hepatitis appear normal or slightly mottled. At the other end of the spectrum, massive hepatic necrosis may produce a greatly shrunken liver.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 7th ed, Pg-899)

choices.text: Bile is present within the tumour cells

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Cholangiocarcinoma (CCA), the second most common primary malignant tumor of the liver after HCC, arises from intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.

They are adenocarcinoma arising from bile ducts epithelium.

Most are well to moderately differentiated.

Markdly desmoplastic, with dens collagenous stroma seprating the glandular elements.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-880-881)

questions.text: Which of the following drug cause chronic active hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Important drugs causing chronic hepatitis: Isonaizide, Halothane, Methyldopa and oxyphenisatin.

(Harrison, 17th ed, Pg-1951)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common malignant testicular neoplasm?
questions.solution:
The most common histologic patterns of germ cell tumors are seminoma, embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, choriocarcinoma, and teratoma. Mixed tumors contain more than one element, most commonly embryonal carcinoma, teratoma, and yolk sac tumor.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-697)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis is defined by the presence of endometrial glands and stroma in a location outside the uterus. It frequently is multifocal and often involves pelvic structures (ovaries, pouch of Douglas, uterine ligaments, tubes, and rectovaginal septum). Less frequently, distant areas of the peritoneal cavity or periumbilical tissues are involved. Uncommonly, distant sites such as lymph nodes, lungs, and even heart, skeletal muscle, or bone are affected.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-721)

questions.text: Which of the following shows bilateral breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Lobular invasive carcinomas have a greater incidence of bilaterality. So, biopsy of opposite breast is adviced.

(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-1085)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic finding of Rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin that principally attacks the joints, producing a nonsuppurative proliferative and inflammatory synovitis.

RA typically manifests as symmetric arthritis principally affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. Grossly, the synovium becomes edematous, thickened, and hyperplastic, transforming its smooth contour to one covered by delicate and bulbous villi. In advanced untreated cases the pannus can bridge the bones to form a fibrous ankylosis, which may later ossify as a bony ankylosis. Rheumatoid nodules are an infrequent manifestation subcutaneous tissue including the forearm, elbows, occiput, and lumbosacral area.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-819-20)

questions.text: Histology of myositis ossificans mimics?
questions.solution:
Osteogenic sarcoma- Central zone contains mature cells and peripheral zone contains more active immature zone.

Myositis ossificans- Central zone contains immature cells and peripheral zone contains more active mature zone.

(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-1251)

questions.text: Which of the following shows Biphasic Pattern?
questions.solution:
In synovial cell sarcoma, epithelial cells are segregated by sarcomatoid cells.

(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-1254)

questions.text: All of the followings are the features of pick's disease Except?
questions.solution:
Frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) encompasses several disorders that preferentially affect the frontal and/or temporal lobes. As a result, these disorders have certain shared clinical features, such as progressive deterioration of language and changes in personality.

One well-recognized subtype of FTLD-tau is Pick disease, which is associated with smooth, round inclusions known as Pick bodies.

Pick disease is a progressive dementia characterized clinically by early onset of behavioural changes together with alteration in personality and language disturbance.

(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-1318)

questions.text: Which is the common nerve in neck from which schwanoma arise?
questions.solution:
Most common nerve in neck from which schwanoma arise is the eighth cranial nerve.

The fifth cranial nerve is the second most frequent site.

(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-1340)

questions.text: All are included in MEN type I tumor Except?
questions.solution:
The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases caused by proliferative lesions (hyperplasias, adenomas, and carcinomas) of multiple endocrine organs.

MEN-1 syndrome is caused by germ line mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene, which encodes a protein called Menin. Organs most commonly involved are the parathyroid, the pancreas, and the pituitary—the “3 Ps.”

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-795)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of Addison's disease?
questions.solution:
Most common cause of primary adrenocortical insufficiency (Adisson’s disease) is autoimmune adrenalitis. Others are: TB, AIDS, Metastatic cancers.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-1156)

questions.text: Brain natriuretic peptide is degraded by?
questions.solution:
Brain natriuretic peptide is a hormone produced by ventricles of heart.

It has been shown to increase in response to ventricular volume expansion and pressure overload.

It is marker of ventricular systolic and dystolic function.

Like atrial natriuretic peptide it is degraded by Neutral endopeptidase.

(Ganong, 22th ed, Pg-462)

questions.text: Which of the following show 'Row of tombstones' appearance?
questions.solution:
Pemphigus is an uncommon autoimmune blistering disorder resulting from loss of normal intercellular attachments within the epidermis and the squamous mucosal epithelium. There are three major variants:

• Pemphigus vulgaris (the most common type)

• Pemphigus foliaceus

• Paraneoplastic pemphigus.

In pemphigus vulgaris, acantholysis selectively involves the layer of cells immediately above the basal cell layer, giving rise to a suprabasal acantholytic blister.

(Robbins Basic Pathology,10th ed, Pg-896)

questions.text: Which of the following does not allow phagocytosis of Tuberculous bacilli?
questions.solution:
Virulent strains of tuberculous bacilli form microscopic “serpentine cord” in which acid fast bacilli are arranged in parallel chains, cord formation is correlated with virulence.

A cord factor has been extracted from virulent bacilli with petroleum ether. It inhibits migration of leucocytes, causes chronic granulomas and can serve as immunologic adjuvant.

(Robbins Basic Pathology,8th ed, Pg-368)

questions.text: Which is the most common vascular tumour in AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency syndrome)?
questions.solution:
Kaposi sarcoma (KS), a vascular tumor that is otherwise rare in the United States, is considered an AIDS-defining malignancy. The lesions of KS are characterized by a proliferation of spindle-shaped cells that express markers of both endothelial cells (vascular or lymphatic) and smooth muscle cells.

(Robbins Basic Pathology,10th ed, Pg-180)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most radiosensitive tissue?
questions.solution:
Radiosensitivity of different organs in decreasing order:

Bone marrow > Testis > Ovary > Kidney > Liver > Lung > Heart > GIT > Thyroid > Brain and spinal cord > Skin and cartilage > Adult bone > Vagina > Uterus.

(Robbins Basic Pathology,8th ed, Pg-424)

choices.text: Increased metabolism of calcium from bone

questions.text: Rickets is due to-
questions.solution:
Rickets is a metabolic disorder characterized by deficient mineralization of bone.

It may be due to-

  1. Vitamin D deficient- Decrease absorption of calcium (Vit D dependent rickets)
  2. Increased phosphate excretion due to defective reabsorption- Vit D resistant rickets

(Robbins Basic Pathology,8th ed, Pg-435)

questions.text: Aphthous ulcer is also known as?
questions.solution:
Aphthous ulcer is also known as cancker’s sores. These are superficial ulcers of oral mucosa. The lesions may single or multiple. Ulceration may be surrounded by erythematous halo and is covered by a thin exudate.

(Robbins, 8th ed, Pg-742)

questions.text: All of the following are involved in tumour metastasis cascade except?
questions.solution:
Invasion of the ECM initiates the metastatic cascade and is an active process that can be resolved into several sequential steps:

Loosening of intercellular connections between tumor cells

Local degradation of the basement membrane and interstitial connective tissue

Changes in attachment of tumor cells to ECM proteins

Locomotion is the final step of invasion, propelling tumor cells through the degraded basement membranes and zones of matrix proteolysis.




(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-220-221)

choices.text: Normal tissue in excess at normal site

questions.text: Define Choristoma
questions.solution:
Heterotopia or choristoma refers to microscopically normal cells or tissues that are present in abnormal locations. Examples are a pancreatic tissue “rest” found in the wall of the stomach or small intestine and a small mass of adrenal cells found in the kidney, lungs, ovaries, or elsewhere. Heterotopic rests usually are of little clinical significance, but on the basis of their appearance they can be confused with neoplasm.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-285)

questions.text: All of the following are radiolucent stones Except?
questions.solution:
Urinary stones-

Cysteine stones - Radiopaque

Uric acid stones – Radiolucent

Xanthiene – Radiolucent (Smith urology, 16th ed,Pg-264)

(Love and bailey, 24th ed, Pg-1316-17)

questions.text: Good pasture syndrome is characterized by?
questions.solution:
Goodpasture syndrome is an uncommon autoimmune disease in which lung and kidney injury are caused by circulating autoantibodies against certain domains of type IV collagen that are intrinsic to the basement membranes of renal glomeruli and pulmonary alveoli. The antibodies trigger destruction and inflammation of the basement membranes in pulmonary alveoli and renal glomeruli, giving rise to necrotizing hemorrhagic interstitial pneumonitis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th ed, Pg-519)

questions.text: Alpha fetoprotein is elevated in case of?
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein is a glycoprotein synthesized normally early in fetal life by the yolk sac, fetal liver and fetal GIT.

It is elevated in – Liver ca, lung ca, colon ca, pancreatic ca, non seminoma germ cell tumour of testis, cirrhosis, hepatitis and pregnancy.

(Robbins Basic Pathology, 8th ed, Pg-327)

questions.text: 10 year manoj complaints of scalp swelling and alopecia. Which of the following is required for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Manoj is suffering from tenia capitis. It is fungal infection which requires KOH scrapping for diagnosis.

(Harrison, 17th ed, Pg-916-17)

questions.text: Which stain is useful for detection of lipid in a tissue?
questions.solution:
Oil red O and sudan black are the stains for lipids.

Muciramine detects epithelial mucin

Myeloperoxidase stain differentiate between the cells of acute myeloid leukemia from acute lymphoid leukemia.

PAS(Peridic acid Schiff) stain detects glycogen and fungi.

(Ananthnarayan, 7th ed, Pg-611)
